4	Ahh, the crave. Having grown up Vietnamese, I consider myself something of an expert on Vietnamese cuisine. So I've had (of course, my grandmother's and mother's food is 5 star), and I've had horrible. Pho Van (putting accents on the vowels is with an American keyboard, so I'm not going to bother) in the middle--not my favorite, but not too bad.We started with appetizers. Cha gio, which is a pork filled roll in a ton wrapper, was okay. It tasted not so fresh, but had filling, and the Nuoc Mam (a fish sauce used to flavor) was okay. My wife and I had Goi Cuon, which is a shrimp and pork, with vermicelli noodle rolled in a rice paper wrapper, was good. This is dipped in a peanut sauce.I had the basic Pho Tai. This is a soup, typically pre-prepared by putting cooked rice vermicelli noodles at the bottom of a bowl, and then very thinly sliced beef, and then Pho broth poured over the soup to essentially reconstitute the noodles and cook the beef. The secret to Pho is really the broth. Typically, this needs to stand on its own to make a judgement. It does--it was flavorful, tasted fresh, and had a very flavor. I was pleased. For my own purposes, I do add Hoisin Sauce and Srirachi Sauce. Having eaten here once before, I knew I wouldn't be disappointed. The only I would have of this Pho is that there's not of it. The standard bowl did not have much in the way of noodles or beef. For $8, I was hoping for more food.The rest of my family members had Bun Thit Nuong Cha Gio. This is a traditional dish with rice vermicelli noodles, barbecued pork, and cha gio, over which you pour Nuoc Mam. There is a bed of vegetables. This is what I typically think of when I think of Asian Salad--it's bean sprouts, lettuce, mint, and cucumber. The barbecued pork tasted quite as did the Cha Gio, once again. I found this food quite as well. The restaurant was very clean, relatively quiet. There's a very fish tank. The decor was very nice. The staff was attentive, and service was quick. I note though that it was 5:30pm on a Friday, and the restaurant was unbusy. The Nuoc Mam very to me though--I'm used to the of this food additive, and this one quite to me. We are talking about something called fish sauce though, so I'm sure there are variants. It tasted so no worries. Staff needs to use towels when they wipe the tables as it does leave its own as well. I swear, they put in their food, because although their breakfast options are simple, they are out of this world. The first time I came here I got the waffles. Perhaps it's because they use REAL maple syrup, or all of the ingredients are organic and locally grown, but they make the waffles I've ever had. I don't even know how one makes a waffle really, it seems formulaic, but it's stellar. I ordered it with bacon, which was also wonderful--the bacon used was the stuff, not the bacon you buy at the supermarket. Every bite is spectacular, and when you're done, you're full, but not the kind of full you'll often get at breakfast joints where you think you're going to or take a nap--full, but refreshed.The second time I came I got the pancakes. Not the pancake I've ever had, but still, and the real maple syrup just sends it through the roof. The third time I went I got the waffle again (see above).Before I came here, I was about leaving Phoenix for New York due to the array of dining options you get in that city. Now I'm there won't be anything as good! [SEP]

4	For a taste of the exotic, the allure of eating without utensils, and a journey to Ethiopia...Lalibela is your dining destination. Although this restaurant is located in a strip mall in Tempe, the African art, woven baskets, and boxes of Harar in the hall (Ehtiopian Lager, which is delicious!) give you a small sense that you have stepped into another world.This stays preserved as you peruse the menu and realize you have never seen anything it, starting with your to pronounce Yekik Alicha (split peas).But do not be daunted by this new territory. Start your adventure to Ethiopia with the Yekemem Shai, a black tea with cinnamon, cardamom & cloves. If you are new to Ethiopian, and not sure what to get, the Lalibela Exclusive is the most combination of dishes you can sample. Here, you will have a smattering of meat and vegetarian dishes ranging from Yebeg Alicha Sega Wat (lamb cubes simmered in kibae, onion, turmeric and herbs) to my personal fave, the Yekik Alicha (split peas cooked with onion, turmeric and herbs).Once the food arrives, the basket of injera (bread closely resembling a crepe) will become your eating utensils. Don't be shy, tear off a piece, and use it to scoop the morsels off the plate and into your expectant mouth. You will not be disappointed. In fact, you may feel as though you have just stepped off University and into a traveling caravan in the Ethiopian desert.Whether you are a carniverous adventurer, or a vegetarian swashbuckler - you will the and flavors of this unique cuisine. Bring a large appetite, as the food is quite filling. Dominant meats are beef, chicken and lamb. Savory veggies to be are lentils, peas, cabbages, and collard greens.For a gustative to finish your meal, order a glass of the traditional Ethiopian wine made from honey.Overall, from the service to the food, to the ambiance, an place to bring friends, or a date ;) [SEP]

5	When cowboys ride off into the sunset, they probably stop at Greasewood Flat for a burger and beer. This rustic little bar is located a bit outside the city near Peak and is definitely the drive! You'll know you are in the spot when you see the antique farm equipment and suddenly feel you are walking up to an Old West saloon. Say hello to the mule on your way in. Outside they have picnic tables, horseshoes, and fire pits (gets out there in the desert!), and on the weekends they have live music and dancing. Inside, the bar is small, and the place is covered in dollar bills and business cards left by cowboys and cowgals. For the nights without live music, don't you fret, they have a jukebox with tons of country hits. The night we went it was the bartender's birthday, and the regulars were definitely having a time. Both a historic landmark (120+-year old original stagecoach stop) and a dive bar, Greasewood Flat is special to Arizona, and is a definite must see. I'll be going back on a weekend to get the true Greasewood Flat experience and hopefully see a cowboy or two.. [SEP]

4	Another indoor (two-story) Westcor Mall that has gone through a few minor changes over the years (updating the restrooms in the Food Court area, adding Dick's as another anchor store, adding the kid's play area, etc...). It's also seen many big and small Retailers come and go too.When this mall opened back in 1994, Robinsons-May was the ONLY store open before the rest of the mall. There were empty fields in the surrounding areas and orange grooves in other parts. It's to believe, but the ONLY restaurant open at the time in the area was Applebee's across the street.Fast forward to today, the Mall still attracts shoppers from all over, since it's the ONLY indoor mall in the West Valley (not counting Sky Mall-don't go there!).Anchor stores: Macy's, Forever 21 (in the former Mervyn's building), Dick's Sporting Goods, JC Penny's, Sears (formally Montgomery Wards), and Dillards.AMC Movie Theater is located inside the mall.Besides the Food Court, there is a Chevy's, Johnny Rockets, and Mile Deli.Some newer Retailers include: Sephora, Coach, Disney Store (they came back!), Apple, Swaroski, and J. Jill. The mall stays full of Retailers, once in awhile, there are a couple of empty stores, but not for very long.This is still a family mall to visit and shop. Westcor keeps it updated and clean. 5	This is a place in an extremity of the Valley. They serve both Korean and Japanese food. They are quick and attentive. Having lived in South Korea for two years, I can honestly admit that this is some of the most Korean cuisine I've had in Phoenix. I typically ate bibimbap once a week minimum over there and I can't really tell the difference between Takamatsu's version and the stuff I had on the other side of the Pacific. I noticed they offer a list of other, more foods I learned to over there, including naengmyeon (cold, spicy noodles), japchae (stir-fried glass noodles), and several other dishes. They also follow tradition and bring you several side dishes. it or it, kimchi accompanies every meal, as do spicy bean sprouts, a tangy spinach dish and a few other random sides. It's a little bit more than average restaurant prices in the Valley, but definitely it when you consider the sides that come with it, and a spiced tea for dessert. [SEP]

4	Had the of House of Tricks last night, for the second time in the past twelve months.With a party of six, I was to get to see a range of dishes and try out most of the menu via my dining companions choices. The restaurant, found in Tempe near ASU, is not to find and houses both indoor and outdoor seating. The outdoor seating is where we ended up last night and between the fire pit in the middle of the grounds and the of trees/greenery, the setting quite well. Our party was seated immediately and without problem, the night was off to a start. Our waitress, Jamie, was both and courteous. Jamie had a understanding of the menu, the specials and especially the wine. Her for multiple members of the party out perfectly. Each person in our party ordered an appetizer and off we went.I had the pork belly, on Jamie's suggestion. Other choices within our party included the salmon cake, sweetbreads two ways, and the scallops. I thought the pork belly was great. It had a pea puree as a base sauce and some baby carrots that just killed. The scallops were tasty and cooked perfectly. The sweetbreads two ways were a bit of a letdown. As a of sweetbreads, I have had the of tasting some of the variations of there preparation. These were just not that great. They weren't cooked and the seasoning was lacking. This would be the only dish of the evening.For the entree, I had the pork osso bucco. This was a real treat, cooked evenly, and tasty. Other entree selections around the table included the ahi tuna, the salmon, and the duck. The tuna was the standard seared on a bed of potatoes. Both diners who chose this selection were quite satisfied. My companion had the duck and while she certainly the dish, she found the duck slightly fatty. All around, the entrees were and plates were cleaned. With little room left for dessert, we ordered three selections for the table to share. All were and once again our plates were cleaned off. The dessert was agreed upon to be the homemade smore the restaurant produces. All in all, this is a restaurant with a atmosphere and service. I would eat here again and you to do the same. [SEP]

Most museums I have been to charge an additional fee. This was unlike any guide I have experienced before. No numbers to in, just walk by any of the exhibits with your headset on and when you stop at each video screen, the audio automatically starts up! When I walked up to the flamenco part of the Spain exhibit I recognized the video playing as I have actually been in the flamenco club in Madrid where it was filmed so I thought that was neat.I really all of the exhibits especially seeing the guts of the Steinway piano and how Martin guitars are made. 3	I really wanted to in with this place, I mean, a British themed pub in Heritage Square? So promising. As you walk in, the bartender is standing behind in an elaborate wooden bar structure. (Would have been if they had Old on tap, but you can't have everything.) Due to the combination of things cooking in the kitchen, it a bit my grandma's house. This prompted us to make a beeline for the patio decorated with super-heavy wood furniture. I assume this is to thieves from selling their tables and chairs on the black market. Smart. The piped-in music selection that night was a bit off-putting, in fact, one of the other patrons commented on it as well. It appeared to be a satellite radio station that specialized in 80s hits Wham! and Depeche Mode. I guess George Michael and David Gahan ARE British. Indeed! Wikipedia just informed me that Dave Gahan (born May 9, 1962 in Epping, Essex, England) is the baritone singer for the English electronic band Depeche Mode, and is also an solo artist. Now I feel better. There are many nooks in this place, so that would be a thing if you wanted to have some one-on-one time. They were also playing football (soccer) on the flat screens, so should make some team scarf-wearing Brit ex-pats in the Valley very happy.Will I be back to try the food? Probably at some point. But, for another round of drinks, I think I'll wait for a Friday or Saturday night when it's hopping. [SEP]

4	Yoli's has recently been popping up on Yelp's 'Best Of' front page. Many people are mouthing out and as the food that I am, I needed to go out and try it for myself.My previous research told me that there were many 5 stars and 3 stars reviews regarding the ambiance, service and food. It seemed that the place had be 5-stars for a while but trending analysis showed a in the late 2011- early 2012. Alright nerd talk- it was a Saturday morning, I was starving and I needed a place to have brunch with my lady friend in town.When it comes to brunch at Yoli's, you really need to leave all your expectations at the door. The neighborhood its in is a little sub-par, the parking situation isn't and the interior and patio decor resembles a home that stopped paying for landscaping services a long time ago. The tables outside are all basic basic plastic, they are not (or leveled) and the seating is limited. If you are coming to Yoli's, you are coming here for the food and nothing else, this ain't no brunch at the Four Seasons.Their menus are breakfast/brunch related but at a 2-sided page list, their breakfast choices do have a large of flavors and prices. The food is on the stealthier side with skillet dishes, omelets and diner-style potato sides. My friend and I ordered their most dish, the El Monte- Hawaiian french toast sandwich filled with egg whites, turkey, bacon and cheese with a 'spicy orange marmalade'. At about $7, the sandwich was large and filled me up easily after just half of it. The french toast itself was and spongy and the bacon had some crisp, but the turkey was very thinly-sliced deli meat so it didn't have a lot of flavor and the spicy marmalade was tasty but not spicy at all.The service was a tad but the lady was very very and to us, she just didn't stop by very often so we had to wait around for our drinks and our check for quite a while. Overall I wasn't blown away with Yoli's but I would as a place with portions and prices. As of now, a 3.75 stars on my book.I am a big of local restaurants and I seeing a family-owned business thrive. With a little bit more decor, service and a environment this place can return to be the that people used to talk about. Yoli, if you are reading this- I hope you take this advice, we all want to see you so we hope you can get back on that horse and the out of us. Luck!! [SEP]

4	I can't believe I didn't write a review of Metro after my first visit but I got a second chance last Saturday night with Dottsy Z, Andrea K and company. When we were finally seated our server was and and had blue eyes. Hello! We were all starving and got to the point with our orders: I started with the cucumber soup and no amount of yums or mmmmms can fully describe the that was set before me. A soup, this is made with cucumbers, buttermilk, dill and olive oil, with chunks of lump crabmeat and a dollop of caviar thrown on top, because why the not?! Also, the soup came in a really large bowl and I was full by the time I finished it. I did soldier on to my main course which was the Moules Frites which is what I had the first time I came here and is a truly inspired dish with juicy mussels, and a broth with thyme, garlic and perhaps a little white wine. Then to add to they serve the huge casoulet with a hearty portion of herbed french fries that were the crispness and didn't leave oil on my hands. I had to leave some of those friends behind, but only because it was time for dessert! I chose pot de creme which is normally topped with brioche. I requested a brioche-free pot and it was no problem. I was served a tiny ramekin of creamy custard topped with a sort of peanut butter syrup/creme and three slices of caramelized banana. It was really yummy though within 10 minutes my heart was racing from all the sugar. I will point out that this dinner took 2 full hours (we left at 11:30PM) making this the longest I ever spent in a restaurant (3.5 hours are you kidding me?) which is why I ultimately docked one star. Based on food alone Metro Brasserie deserves 10 stars. [SEP]

4	We upon this little place in a strip mall by accident, but it ended up being a very accident. Yes, it is true that the decor will not be gracing the pages of fashion magazines anytime soon, but this is a clean, no-frills kind of place. There is also no point in coming here if you are pressed for time, because it is not food by any stretch of the imagination. Most importantly, the food is good. Really good. The menus must have changed since other reviewers visited, because there was no Arabic on the menu. Everything is in English. I had the falafel plate and my companion had the lamb shank and rice. Both meals came with a lentil soup that I have had at Fattoush many times- but this one was so much better. The falafel plate came with falafel of course, a salad, pita that looked homemade, and some of the tastiest hummus i've ever had. It was a huge amount of food, but it was so that I was compelled to order an extra side of hummus to go with the leftovers. The lamb was apparently very tasty also- i'm not much of a lamb fan, so I didn't try it. The accompanying rice was very tasty though- very with many different flavors, but none of them were overwhelming. At 7.99 for the falafel and 9.99 for the lamb plate, the prices are more than reasonable, especially when you consider that each entree can easily end up being two meals. I admit that I am partial to Middle-Eastern food and rarely meet a falafel that I dislike, but this was definitely one of the examples of the cuisine in the metro Phoenix area. I will definitely be back, and maybe next time i'll try the chicken. [SEP]

Not at all considering we will each be getting 2 or more meals out of it. We're & would definitely order from them again...maybe even dine in eventually! [SEP]

5	Do Taco Jedis at Senor Taco? Yes. Yes they do.Is the force of making Mexican food with these Jedis? Oh yeah!Try the shredded beef tacos in the shells. When they ask you if you want sauce, say 'si' and drizzle it onto the tacos. Piled cheese, beef, lettuce, tomatoes all stuffed into an authentic-style taco shell - it doesn't get any than this. Just make sure you put a helmet on because it's good.If you spicy, no-nonsense burritos, go with the Carne Asada Burrito (Red Chile).If you the whole meal, go with the Carne Asada or Pollo Asado burrito combo plates. The plate comes with flour tortillas, beans and rice, guacamole and salsa fresca. You make your own burritos. This is just eatin'. Take it home, open a Hefeweizen, and you are golden.And lastly, from the sage words of my wife: The shrimp tacos and burritos are certified gourmet meals! Do I stutter? Nope.While Senor Taco is technically 'fast food' it does take some time to prepare. If you do drive-thru don't get all road ragey if it takes longer than it does at Taco Bell. There is a price to pay to make food and that price is TIME. This is not a worldwide chain that spends more on advertising and earning your business by putting little dogs on plastic mugs. Senor Taco is not that type of place. A little wait is very much it.I realize that appearance of the location some reviewers. Yes, it is in a strip mall. Yes it is 100-150 feet away from a gas station slash AM/PM mini market. I get that. But this is not Sanctuary. This is not Kai. This is not Deseo. When one reviewer (and I use the word 'reviewer' loosely here) hilariously claims to have walked in, used his Superman vision to supposedly spot a family of microbes and (without trying the food) proceeded to sprint out because he was frightened of all the imagined cooties ... well... I just have to laugh. That's not a review, it's a drive-by, and reviewers this are probably with Hometown Buffet or Luby's Cafeteria. And that's too because this is food.I've eaten here maybe 15-20 times and my wife has ordered the fish taco plate a number of times and neither of us has ever gotten sick. The people at Senor Taco are nice, the food surprises and your expectation of Mexican food will be forever changed for the better. I can't highly enough. [SEP]

He's plainly feeling good, so just feed him a diet, give him this medication to settle his stomach, and bring a stool sample just in case, so you know for sure he's parasite-free. He also dispensed advice for Nately's general care, as long as we were there, about heartworm prevention and necessary vaccines, etc. I even got a education on the different types of parasites and which were even likely in AZ's climate (turns out, not many). If only they treated birds too! [SEP]

5	I now have a sixth Sens for Asian tapas- a genre I never knew existed. I always assumed the tapas disappeared when Aaron May sauteed Sol Y Sombra's last batch of butter-marinated brussels sprouts! I tried three items:Wasabi Tofu- Hot, in every Sens of the word. Wasabi and 300-degree tempura crusties have the ability to you to your soul if you aren't careful. Don't skip it, just poke it with a chopstick or on it first. White Juice and Vodka- Just Japanese candy exchange students brought home in high school, it's one of those flavors most Americans will never have the opportunity to try. Light and sweet, but not overly so, it's a blend you can sip all.night.long. (I did!)The best, by far, is the & Soup. It's nothing the kind you get for .99 at Chinese restaurants as an appetizer. A Bilbo Baggins-ey cauldron arrives with a wooden ladle- among the various veggies and disc-shaped noodles is your choice of meat- I chose clams. I've always heard you can truly tell how a chef is by how tasty his soup is, and would have to agree. There's nothing to hide behind, and you're confronted by flavor. It was complex, different and mouthwatering.The whole Sens-ation was so genius, I even got past the of Chef Johnny Chu snorting in my face for taking pics of my meal on my iPhone. [SEP]

I would definitely go back for the ambiance and tasty take on Mexican food. [SEP]

5	I have been to every ballpark in the Cactus League and know my way around them all. This is, by far, the facility in all of Spring Training (that includes the Florida parks). Granted, I am a Dodger fan and we get it than the 'Sox do, but it is still amazing.Camelback Ranch is the brand new, state of the art, spring training facility for the Dodgers and White Sox. The Sox moved from Tucson because Tucson is the literally SO that even people from CHICAGO won't stay there. The park is located just south of the Glendale Airport and much only has one way in or out - 111th Ave. You can avoid Camelback Rd by taking Indian School to 111th and then just drive into the stadium.The grounds feature 13 practice fields and a giant lake and river that also help irrigate the fields. While the White Sox practice fields and clubhouse entry are blocked off from the public, the Dodgers' are wide open and inviting. Players must walk through the crowds during practices which invited lots of interaction with the fans. The field is and the layout of the stadium is quite impressive. Not only do they have a full Jumbotron but they also feature fully enclosed suites and a full buffet for those to shell out $90 per game. That price gets you seats behind home, access to food, wine, beer, soda, and sweets. It also gets you exclusive merchandise as as towels to help you off. It sounds a lot but it turns out to be the money.The grass seats have a slope to them (much Scottsdale) and the seat aisles are wide. The food selection is without Dodger Dogs, however. The stadium is also missing the independent food vendors that Maryvale and Peoria feature. A stadium and surely one to visit every March. [SEP]

Meet me at Monkey Pants. Yes, Monkey Pants!And so I did. Monkey Pants! folks, but this name is nonsensically awesome. I walked in and sat myself at the round bar, joining a smattering of other patrons sitting there by themselves, each staring into nowhere in particular. drinks for $2.50, served in a standard kitchen glass. Nice! I proceeded to watch the football game and was soon joined by my Tempe tour guide.We were approached by the bartender to do discounted Patron shots....but only if we wore sombreros. There was barely anyone here on a Sunday night, and I'm of the kind who doesn't care anyway, and the thought of me and Bonnie G sitting at a stripmall bar with sombreros on is kind of and at the same time, but shots were not on my agenda for the night. Alas.I then got a royal tour of the place, including the leg lamp (actually it's two legs, not just one!), shuffleboard, pool tables, couches with a fire being played on endless loop on a big screen TV, board games and another section with tables and chairs, which is where we sat, under the painting of the teddy bear in Richard Simmons gear. Other patrons were seated all over the large space, so everyone had their own private area in a way. I actually really dug this. I'm not one who needs a place to be to myself or feel it's happening. Sitting around a fire with pints and board games with a few friends is more my speed these days anyway. So I may sound decrepit, but I'm really not that old. I swear.Sure, Monkey Pants has frat-party throughout the day, but this place has no whatsoever. How can you even take it seriously? Even it doesn't take itself seriously. I mean, it's just sitting there. In a strip mall. In Tempe. With a painting of a teddy bear wearing Richard Simmons workout gear on the wall and a stack of sombreros sitting next to a popcorn machine. Waiting for you to leave your mind behind and the now.And the now we did. All thanks to my Tempe tour guide.4 stars.(end of Part One) [SEP]

Given the size, this easily was a 4 egg omelet. Breakfast with drinks ran about $20 which was for all the food I got. But I would be remiss if I didn't talk about what really blew me away about this place. It's the service! Everyone seems to be part of a larger team. I was greeted by one person, seated by another and had at least three servers taking care of me. And countless people stopped by to ask how things were, if I needed more water for my tea, or if I wanted more preserves for my toast. It was unbelievable! While they have been open for 9 months- they had the staff of a place that has been open much longer. The ambiance is contemporary but is warmed up by the blue booths, table cloths, and some mismatched dining tables in the center that can be expanded for larger groups. There are also antique food cases lining the walls filled with tins of chocolate, and other food cues. I also that they have those roll up doors on the one side that bring the outdoors in and seats outside on those days. If I lived in Scottsdale- this would be my go to brunch place. What I don't get is why people are waiting in line at a place around the corner that left me a little cold. C'mon people. If you haven't checked Bacon out- you should. After all- what's not to about, Bacon? [SEP]

3	I usually shop at this store because it is the most and has the prices and selection in the area. Their branded goods (Kroger) such as condiments are usually quality compared to store brands at other stores. However, in the last few years, vegetable prices have skyrocketed (other than tomatoes, celery, and lettuce) so I find myself driving several miles away to a food specialty store to stock up. This Fry's was recently renovated, seemingly to make it more to find the items you are looking for, and making what should be a quick trip in an out into a half-hour ordeal. The aisles also seem to be harder to navigate, with displays jutting out here and there, and it's to get around other customers. What I do is that there are four self-checkouts so you usually don't have to wait in lines. I also Fry's policy of charging you the price on the shelf-tag, or you get the item free. I've often walked out with cash in my pockets when I went in with none. Sometimes due to the VIP customer pricing on the receipt, it's a bit to tell if you paid the price. Read your receipt carefully! [SEP]

5	Say hello to the Ghost Lounge, folks. This is a brand new bar located next to Seamus, within the San Carlos through an agreement with the hotel's ownership. For years, I've thought the Hotel San Carlos was an under-appreciated (through its own fault) downtown venue. With the Ghost, the owner has finally executed a plan to its place on the downtown Phoenix scene. This is apparent from the first step inside the lobby, which appears as it did in 1928 when the hotel first opened. If celebrities in the 1930s had to spend the night in Phoenix, back then a small, un-airconditioned cowboy town with around 50,000, they would have stayed here. (Or else the near-by Westward Ho). You get a taste of those times with the massive photographic blow-ups the Ghost has put up on its walls of various scenes from early 20th century downtown Phoenix. So large that you can zero in on individual pedestrians on the streets, and at their bowties, cowboy hats, handkerchiefs and facial expressions. Back then, the San Carlos was probably one of the only places in town that was air-cooled. (That may have meant it had swamp coolers. I haven't googled the history of air conditioning technology for this review.)I'd describe the bar's style as grandiose, and old school Phoenix with an obligatory hint of Chicago (obligatory given the decades-old economic relationship betweeen the two cities that endures to this day). It has been done. I will be back often. [SEP]

I have a with gluttony so I can't suggest a single dish - I can only suggest them all. However, this place also has some of the Salt and Pepper calamari I've ever had. [SEP]

4	Every culture has their soup. American's have chicken noodle, Mexican's have menudo and Vietnamese have pho. I must have been Vietnamese in a past life. Pho is the national dish of Vietnam and a staple at any Vietnamese restaurant and Pho Avina has some of the pho around. Let me warn you - this isn't an appetizer, this is a meal. A big, steaming bowl of soup served with your choice of meat and noodles in a savory, almost sweet, broth. The pho is served with a large plate of basil, cilantro and bean sprouts; the cilantro complimented the soup nicely. I chose the chicken and shrimp and was surprised with large shrimp and big chunks of all white chicken. My eyes were bigger than my stomach, so I also ordered the deluxe vermicelli salad. A salad of noodles, veggies, beef, chicken, shrimp, eggroll, potato cake and fish sauce - toss together and enjoy. I had it boxed up, but did nibble on a few items and the potato cake is out of this world good. I had come for the banh mi at the of a previous yelper. They only serve the sandwiches Monday-Friday from 11-3; I had just them. Darn. I will definitely be back to try the banh mi and a boba, there were soooo many flavors to choose from except for the durian - icky, icky, icky. [SEP]

The Herb Box also has a patio with big windows opening to the bar and comfortable, fireplaces. This is such a location in old town and steps away from the mall, I know it will become a regular place for me. [SEP]

The place is small and and crowded, a blues bar in an old converted house should be. varies by night but anytime you go it's passable. Personal favorites are lady J and Bam Bam and any combination thereof, which is what you usually get any way. 4	Sitting at the counter at FnB is an experience that should be had, period. Our reservations by default was later on in the evening, but also turned out to be quite fortuitous. Not only were we able to see chefs Badman and Curry in action, but also saw them turn down the kitchen towards the end of the night. It is a display that even the most advent epicurean is not often exposed to. There are no doors or walls to hide behind. Everything that you eventually place in your mouth is out in the open and also in the way it is prepared - from the raw, to the stove, to the plate. was also how fluid the kitchen moved with only the two chefs preparing dishes. Chef Curry preparing the appetizers, fish and fowl; while Chef Badman shoveled coal onto a grill and simultaneously manning it to ensure rib-eyes were cooked to order. The ambiance was the type you'd expect when invited into another's kitchen, and the food tasted as if given the same attention. So to the service. Our waitress, Chantelle was about explaining everything to us after hearing that it was our first time there. When she found out we had moved just a few months ago, she was kind to write down her restaurant for us too. Will definitely be back to try other items off their ever-evolving menu. Reservation for two please. Yes its okay if its at the counter and yes, its if its late. [SEP]

4	When shopping is an adventure and a destination, you must be heading to Tan Phat. This is a Asian market that has been there for me whenever I need water chestnuts (for wrapping in bacon, and they carry five different brands! Who knew so many companies were in the business of the water chestnut?) or kitchen supplies for Asian themed dinners. One of the first things that hits you upon entering in the of seafood. After acclimating to that, you'll find a huge selection of canned goods, dried seafood and mushrooms, a selection of produce and an amount of edibles (you know, those package foodstuffs that you just can't find outside of Asian markets). The employees are usually polite. You may have to walk through every aisle to find what you need, but that's part of the adventure. [SEP]

3	Friday night after a long workweek seemed to be a time to treat ourselves to a new cuisine, so my friend and fellow yelper John M. and I decided to check out this Uzbek restaurant. The interior would be mostly generic in appearance were it not for the somewhat ornate Middle-Eastern curtains, and a TV screen playing Uzbek and Russian music videos added to the ambiance. Large pictures of the main dishes in the counter area show you what they offer even before you are seated and handed a menu. For starters, we ordered Uzbek salad - tomatoes, cucumbers and white onions lightly drizzled with a dill vinaigrette - and blinchik, which are crepes with a flavorful meat and onion stuffing; beware, the blinchik are rather filling by themselves. We also ordered palov and lamb kebabs. The palov was a dish of tasty rice with carrots and meat, and was quite a choice. The lamb kebabs were juicy and flavorful, though the rice that came with it was on the dry side. A small basket of pita bread rounded up the meal. In all, it was a meal, not great, but definitely satisfying. And I do hope to try the soup dishes next time. [SEP]

4	After reading the other reviews, I thought perhaps I would weigh in - they seem to be all over the place. The are that the decor seems dated. To me, having grown up back east with this very sort of restaurant, it was charming. The restaurant is particularly to visit at night, when they turn on the lights in the garden. I the layout of the dining room, although I agree it is a 'cooler' experience to eat in the bar. I guess some people could be offended that the staff sit down and eat in the bar when it is slow, but I'm not one of those people - I think it adds to the charm. I had a very late lunch yesterday - around 3 - thanks to an appointment that went on forever. So we ended up heading to Riazzi's for a late dinner, around 8:30. At that time of the evening, the dining room was closed., so we sat in the bar.Their service is truly one of the strengths of this restaurant. On this night, they were - even for them. The waters came out immediately upon sitting down, then they took your drink order - as it should be. Neither my iced tea or water ever got below half a glass. This is something I occasionally find at places where the staff draws a lot of attention to itself when they refill drinks - particularly when it interrupts the flow of conversation. Not at Riazzi's - they are but unobstrusive. Their bread is my restaurant bread in the Valley - hands down. It is actually than the Italian bread I grew up eating back east in Hartford, New York, Boston and Providence. It's so that I wish they had loaves available. You have to possess a lot of discipline not to fill up on the bread.The salad is as others have described it - traditional, but fresh. My item on the menu is now listed under pizzas and described as a Spinach Pie. This used to be listed under appetizers as the Grass Pie, but if you order a Grass Pie, they'll still know what you mean. It is a cheeseless pizza with spinach and arrabiata sauce. Confession: I all things arrabiata. But this combination here is perfect. For about 1.50 (I can't recall the exact figure), they'll add mozzarella to it, but I've never done that because it is as it. They bring you a amount of tasty parmesan cheese, so you can always throw that on the Spinach Pie.So, I had that. as usual. My wife ordered the Penne Primavera, which was very good. Last time I was there with my daughter, she had the penne with garlic and oil, which I thought was just superb. Simple, but for a garlic fan me. I have a feeling most folks skip over such an entree in of something more elaborate, but I it. We didn't have an appetizer, and even though I wouldn't describe the portions as enormous, they were and neither of us could finish our entrees.Is Riazzi's going to be for the young, hip crowd? Probably not, although it is at night with their lights and sunken/elevated dining room, and has the 'cool' factor of the bar. It totally hit my 'nostalgic for the east-coast Italian restaurant' needs. I just wish the service at most modestly-priced Valley eateries approached Riazzi's. You can get with the bread and service over here. [SEP]

4	Okay, eating Thai food in what seems to be an old diner is kinda weird. But after getting off of long flights, my mother and I needed some kind of Asian food and quick. The spring rolls were okay, but they were tiny and not piping hot.This was a way for us to start our trip and the food hit the spot. I'm all about the mom-and-pop shops and when the kids are working for the parents, I feel for them even more (been there, done that). With a parking lot and some remodeling to get rid of the diner feel, this place will continue to attract more and more clients. [SEP]

5	This is one Ethiopian restaurant, rivals anything I've sampled in Washington DC or Seattle. If I lived in Phoenix, this would be a Top-5 restaurant for me (along with Lo-Lo's Chicken & Waffles - yum!).Lalibela takes a slightly different approach to their menu. Many of the entrees are offered as small portions ($4.50-$6.00 each). They suggest each diner order 2-3 of these to make a meal. Kitfo and Lamb Tibs dishes are offered as full entrees and many Ethiopian restaurants, you can order combo plates (meat combo, veggie combo, house combo plate etc.). This made deciding on our meal a little more complicated, but also offered more for sampling different dishes.Our dish ordered was the Lamb Tibs (the spicy version with Awaze spice paste). Lamb was soooo tender, and the spices were a - in flavor but not too for those with tame palettes. thing it comes as a full order - four of us were competing for bites!! We ordered a half portion of Keye Wott (beef in a spicy brown sauce) that was some of the I've ever had. Again, in flavor but not too spicy. My Ethiopian meat dish is Kitfo - choice beef sort of steak tartar (servered raw or lightly cooked) but with Ethiopian spices. Lalibela's was good, just not transcendent the Lamb Tibs or Beef Keye Wott. The vegetable dishes were on a whole - especially the yellow lentils, gomen (collard greens) and spicy (Wott) lentils.Staff was - attentive, service. Unlike some Ethiopian restaurants, this one is very user-friendly. Although in some cases the menu accommodates American tastes it doesn't compromise on quality or authenticity. One note on the injera (sponge-like bread used to scoop up the entrees) - it's a mix of wheat flour and teff (a grain indigenous to Ethiopia) and I don't think it's fermented injera that is made with 100% teff. I'm used to the latter, but you can argue Lalibela's injera doesn't compete with the flavor of the entrees as much.All in all, one of the Ethiopian restaurants I've been to, and I have been to many in the States. Only now is whether my Ethiopian restaurants in Seattle will still taste as good! Highly, highly recommended. [SEP]

Having a father who grew up on Los Olivos I remained a customer, that is, until last evening's change in plans lured me to the colorfully lit and patio of Los Sombreros Mexican Cafe & Cantina. I am not an expert on Mexican cuisine nor will I to know what the flavors of San Miguel de Allende taste like; however, I am a foodie so I know food when I eat it. We chose to sit outdoor and the weather while taking in another Cardinal's loss! (Sad, I know, since they were off to a start).... for us it was a Monday night and we had the full attention of our waiter, aka the bartender. Phil (no need to blush if you read this) did a job walking us through their many margarita selections while also conveying his personal favorites that showcased his for whiskey! My friend allowed Phil to make his margarita as he felt a margarita should be made while I allowed Phil to concoct my special margarita while following no sugar, no salt, heavy on the tequila preferences...and that was just to start! crafted margaritas in hand, check. Now what to eat for dinner. My friend ordered his Mole poblano ($18.95) while I couldn't decide between the Smoked chicken enchiladas with salsa verde and chipotle crema (yumm) and the Pollo a la parilla with spinach in a chipotle cream sauce -or- tinga Poblana sauce($18.95). I opted for the Pollo a la parilla with chipotle cream preparation and, once again, my dinner friend had 'order envy'!! That's not to say his Mole was par (or dare I say sub-par) because it wasn't - it actually has received many culinary being named Mole both locally and nationally, but because the chipotle cream sauce combined with spinach, saut√©ed chicken breasts and a side of corn tortilla is....AMAZZZZZZING!!!! It's also that I note aside from the entree dishes served w two sides (as we ordered), they also offer up tacos (3 at $10.95), various quesadillas (@ $5.95) and other lesser priced eats including guacamole, salads and more! Deciding I'd save room to see if they could my tooth I boxed my remaining dinner as we read through each and every dessert. Undecided, again, and so we our gastronomy guide, Phil, to choose. He selected the Mexican Chocolate Cream Pie to finish off the evening, and we finished off this treat leaving one bite as I always to do!!! you, Phil and Los Sombreros, for the dining experience. The food was outstanding, margaritas made by Phil are the best, and the patio alone is to draw me back for HH or even a late night dessert. you for staying in the neighborhood, Azucena Tovar, and congrats on almost turning 20 years old. [SEP]

5	Only 4 stars? (A few notes: The folks that rated this place low must have been incidences and I feel weigh far to heavy on service rather than product. Dining at a restaurant, rate the service a lil' harder, but a coffee shop, hold your tongue.)Anyway, this place rocks. We aren't close, but we pass up several coffee shops en route to Lola because the quality is drawer.The beans, trade, and the roast is perfect. The price of a bag of beans is amazing. Doing by the farmers and then respecting the product with such a roast. This is what is all about!I have yet to find a americano. A splash of cream and a splenda only augments the flavor of the espresso and the really shines. I've been to most of the independent coffee shops throughout the area, and if I do find myself elsewhere, I can only compare them to Lola, and Lola out each time. [SEP]
5	I'm not normally one to jump at reviewing a chain restaurant, especially when there are 3 subways all within a couple blocks of each other. I felt it was necessary in this case. My husband and I came here over the weekend after a trip to the dog park. The two guys working here on the afternoon were awesome. They were really and friendly, and quite chatty. One of them started my husband and the other one was while I was deciding. The boy apparently noticed I was and he quickly ran to the back, washed his hands, threw on gloves and asked me what I wanted. WOW! This type of service has never happened at the other locations, all of which I have been too. He chatted with me as I told him what I wanted. He also joked about my sandwich and made me laugh. It's to see a couple guys working on a day and actually themselves. They also have outdoor seating which are to sit at and people watch on days. We even met this 90 year old guy who is and in both ears but somehow managed to communicate with us perfectly. He was much more than most twenty-somethings you meet. Amazing. Only in downtown do you meet people that. This is a Subway. Go here and skip the others. [SEP]

5	Let's see...what is there NOT to about Surprise Stadium? Well, $9.50 tall cans of PBR is about all I could come up with and that's not a surprise (pun intended) considering you're attending a sporting event...even spring training. But as someone who does not living in Arizona, and as someone who doesn't go to MLB baseball games in Southern California due to the fact it costs so much, people bitching about the service or any other little when it comes to seeing a game here. Look, you're to have almost an entire month of low cost MLB baseball in your back yard. If I could, I'd live down here during March just to take in the baseball action that crisscrosses the Phoenix metro area each year. I attended my first spring training game on March 12th, 2012 at Surprise Stadium as the Royals took on the San Francisco Giants (my team). Our seats (Sec. 112, Row J, Seats 13-14-15) were 25 bucks each (around 30 bucks including service fees). I mean, we were maybe 5 or 6 rows back from the Giants dugout (check out some of my pictures). The stadium (funny calling it that since it only holds just over 10,000 people) is big so you feel you're at an MLB game but small to feel close and with the players. The stadium is maintained and kept clean. Arriving to the park, I was surprised (pun unintended) to see that parking was free, an when going to an event this. The stadium staff, as mentioned by other reviews, are mainly made up of senior citizens who were and helpful. I didn't have to wait long at the stands, even if lines were a bit long. The outfield is lined with a lawn area, for people to sit back and have a picnic while taking in a game (Tickets are around 9 bucks each after service fees!!!). I this place and hope to return next year when visiting family. Oh, Giants 2-1! Go Giants!!! [SEP]

4	I recently visited Olive and Ivy for business last week, and after 3 visits, I am convinced that Fox Restaurants has some of the establishments in the valley. Olive and Ivy is the Fox Restaurant of choice for food, drinks, and most of all, service. I spend a lot of time in various restaurants across the valley and am always at how service can be at some of the more valley restaurants. Not Olive and Ivy. From the first phone call for reservations, to the greeting upon walking in the door to the and reception you receive from every server you cross, this restaurant knows how to make you feel special.Many of the reviews here will focus on the food and I could spend hours talking about my experiences but I will sum it up in a couple of my favorites. I dates and prunes, but the bacon wrapped dates are good!The shrimp and risotto main course is one of the dishes I have tasted since arriving in Phoenix 3 years ago. And hands down, their short rib entree is in the valley.The only catch is the cost. Olive and Ivy is not and definitely not for brothers looking to execute the date. With wine, apps, and main course, you will the century mark, and if you are really being generous, $200 is obtainable. But, it's every dollar and who knows, you may even get breakfast out of the deal! [SEP]
